variants.HGVS: N.D. (No specific HGVS nomenclature provided in the literature, need to further query relevant gene databases and use API to standardize once specific cDNA/protein change information is obtained)
variants.Description in input context: A30P, E46K, and A53T point mutations

Material used.Material Source: Protein (WT and PD - linked mutants of αS)
Material used.Material Name: Wild type (WT), and Parkinson disease (PD) mutants A30P, E46K, and A53T of αS
Material used.Description: Double cysteine mutants of WT, and PD mutants A30P, E46K, and A53T of αS were expressed, purified, and spin - labeled with MTSSL as described in the literature. Proteins were prepared in different buffer conditions and membrane mimetics.

Readout description.Conclusion: The A30P mutant retains the ability to adopt both the broken helix and extended helix forms. At higher protein - to - lipid ratios, a distance distribution characteristic of unbound protein was observed for A30P in bicelles. In rod - like micelles, it has a maximally probable distance of 5.5 (ΔR 2.3) nm with a broader distance distribution.
Readout description.Result Description: For A30P mutant in different membrane mimetics (micelles, liposomes, bicelles), specific distance distributions were measured. In LPPG micelles with spin labels at 24/61 positions, a single maximally probable distance of around 4.5 nm was found, indicating the broken helix conformation. In rod - like micelles at 450 mM SDS with spin labels at 24/61, a maximally probable distance of 5.5 (ΔR 2.3) nm was observed. In bicelles, at higher protein concentrations, it showed a distribution with a shorter maximally probable distance resembling unbound protein.

Readout description.Conclusion: The E46K mutant retains the ability to adopt both the broken helix and extended helix forms. The data appear nearly identical to those of the WT protein in vesicle - or bicelle - bound states.
Readout description.Result Description: In rod - like micelles at 450 mM SDS with spin labels at 24/61, a single distance of 5.6 (ΔR 1.5) nm was observed, consistent with the extended helix conformation. In LPPG micelles with spin labels at 24/61 positions, a single maximally probable distance of around 4.5 nm was found, indicating the broken helix conformation.

Readout description.Conclusion: The A53T mutant retains the ability to adopt both the broken helix and extended helix forms. The data appear nearly identical to those of the WT protein in vesicle - or bicelle - bound states.
Readout description.Result Description: In rod - like micelles at 450 mM SDS with spin labels at 24/61, a single distance of 5.7 (ΔR 1.2) nm was observed, consistent with the extended helix conformation. In LPPG micelles with spin labels at 24/61 positions, a single maximally probable distance of around 4.5 nm was found, indicating the broken helix conformation.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: The distance analysis of experimental time domain data has been conducted using the L - curve Tikhonov regularization method to yield inter - spin distance distributions from which average distances and their variations were inferred. The distance distributions produced by the L - curve method were refined, as needed, by the maximum entropy method (MEM). In some cases, they were further analyzed by fitting with one or two Gaussians using a MATLAB script.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on general knowledge, for distance measurements in this context, normal would be consistent with expected distances for known conformations of the protein, e.g., distances corresponding to broken or extended helix conformations as previously established in the literature)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on general knowledge, abnormal would be distances that deviate significantly from expected distances for known conformations of the protein)

Approved assay.Approved assay: Yes (Pulsed dipolar ESR is a commonly used method for studying protein - protein distances and conformations in the context of neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's)
